mobile app for digital arcade tokens

BarQode

mobile app ui/ux logo design

My Role
Project Lead
UI/UX Design
UX Research

Team
Aubrey K. Young (Solo)

Project Duration
3 months

the situation

Arcade patrons want to distribute digital arcade tokens to avoid carrying pockets full of tokens around with them. BarQode removes the need to carry arcade tokens while also adding a modern social aspect to old-school arcade games.

the goal

As a past, present and future gamer myself, I wanted to create a mobile app for BarQode Arcade that allows users to purchase, share, and use tokens from their mobile devices.

Understanding the user

Research Summary

I conducted interviews with 5 people who play video games and use mobile technology to purchase and plan group activities. In return, I offered my continued friendship and an “IOU” for any work-related task with which they may need my help in the future.

Goal: I want to discover if modern mobile interactions, like social sharing, mobile pay, and money transfer are readily translated to a retro arcade setting.

Participants: Adults between 25-50 years old and of different ethnic/cultural backgrounds, who live and work in metropolitan or suburban areas.

research results

The following pain points emerged from my initial user study, as follows:

1
Digital purchase
users want the freedom to choose between purchasing game tokens and digital game credits
2
Token distribution
frequent users and larger parties find it cumbersome to distribute tokens within their groups
3
Activity tracking
stat nerds do not have a way of tracking their arcade habits and high scores

personas

After analyzing the interview data, 2 personas emerged:

Competitive Analysis

An analysis of 4 local and national arcade venues revealed distinct strengths and weaknesses in their pay systems, mobile apps, and reward programs.

Dave & Buster’s Power Cards keep track of rewards and are easy to recharge in-store or through the app. However, users cannot share credits with the Power Card to play arcade games.

EightyTwo is an adult-oriented barcade with retro games and extensive drink menu. However, its stripped-down lounge approach does not include a mobile app or rewards system.

Lucky Strike Lanes is a bowling alley that caters to the entire family. However, since arcades are secondary entertainment, there is no social or interactive component to recreate the retro arcade feel.

Neon Retro Arcade uses a unique all-you-can-play for select time periods model. However, they cater to an under-21 base and lack an online/social presence.

Opportunities

Post analysis, I identified the following opportunities to help BarQode stand out from the competition:

1

provide both digital mobile pay system AND token system

2

provide a gamer rewards system through the app that allows users to earn off-site

3

ensure website is responsive and has the same functions of the mobile app

Low Fidelity Design

My Approach

While including the ability to easily share tokens is Gerald’s goal, Kelly and her husband could also take advantage of this feature with her children. On the other hand, Kelly would love to have further rating information on video games, while Gerald may want to track scores and stats for games if his coworkers are interested in future BarQode outings.

Therefore, BarQode’s mobile app can fulfill both opportunities by make token purchase and sharing easy while also having game stats readily available for users.

User Flow

The main user task is to first purchase, then distribute, digital arcade tokens.

Lo-fi Wireframes (Paper)

Old-school pen to paper to sketch my ideas and basic layout for the app. I emphasized the ‘Play,’ ‘Purchase,’ and ‘Share’ buttons for immediate user engagement.

Lo-fi Wireframes (Digital)

Mobile: I emphasized large, engaging images reminiscent of a streaming service, and a signup button above the fold to engage users immediately.

Lo-fi prototype

Lo-fi Usability Testing

  • same 5 participants from the User Study
  • moderated study
  • ~10 min per study

    • The following findings emerged from this round of usability testing, which I used to create my hi-fi mockups.

    1
    "How do I actually play an arcade game?"

    Problem: users had trouble locating the Play button on the Home screen

    Solution: Play button stands out front-and-center in the bottom menu, along with other sensible icons for easy recognition.

    2
    “There’s a lot going on with the share credits screen.”

    Problem: users report Share Credits screen presents too much information.

    Solution: To reduce clutter, I split the Share Credits screen into 2 separate screens and redesigned the buddy selection window to a scroll area.

    3
    Bonus: Tutorial screens

    Problem: Users appreciate explanations of unfamiliar functions.

    Solution: I created a short 3-slide tutorial for first-time users. The tutorial can be exited or repeated at any point from the Main Menu.

    High Fidelity Design

    Colors & Fonts

    BARQODE’s colors are dark to accompany the lighting in a standard arcade hall - dimly lit with bright pops of attention-grabbing color guiding users to their game of choice.

    #674bda
    #fbca37
    #29a8e8
    #ff5c72

    The logo font Equinox is reminiscent of old-school space shooter games, while the body font Maven Pro is a modern, legible sans-serif with fun character variants.

    coup de grâce: final screens

    BARQODE represents an app that includes both ease of use for a first-time user, and in-depth features to add a social aspect to their arcade play.

    VIEW HI-FI PROTOTYPE!

    Following Steps

    As we get used to hanging out in public again, social connection and safety is as important as it has ever been. BarQode reduces one of many common touchpoints in a venue, introduces a modern digital social aspect, and is a fitting reintroduction to social life.

    Here are a few ideas to capitalize on further iterations:

    1
    User Profile Customization

    Allow users to attach an existing social media account to their BarQode profile

    2
    Gamer Rewards system

    A rewards system would work perfectly in a competitive/ cooperative arcade setting

    3
    Gaming History

    I didn’t include this point in the final project, but I would conduct more user research to determine the benefits to users of a Gaming History section
